description: From late Middle English compteroller, a spelling variant of countreroller (from which controller) due to folk etymology: the word was thought to have an etymological connection with Middle French compte (“account”) (Middle French compteroleur is attested circa 1375). Originally the two spellings were equivalent and pronounced identically; the modern pronunciation with [mp] is based on the spelling.

entries.meaning: The chief accountant of a company or government.
examples: The terms of the licence shall, in default of agreement, be settled by the comptroller.
